video.title: Beyond Good and Evil | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

&quot;Beyond Good and Evil, what&#39;s that?&quot; you younger 
viewers might be asking. &quot;I have never heard of

that because it is unrelated to vaping or 
TikToks.&quot; Well, gather round, stupid kids,

and I&#39;ll tell you a tale of - no, not that close, 
I need to maintain deniability. There are many

things you may take for granted in this day and 
age but there was once a time when Nintendo was

best known as a playing card company, when Sony 
was best known for portable cassette players,

and when Ubisoft made games that weren&#39;t shit. 
Believe it or not there was once a time when

they made quality, artistically driven single 
player games like Prince of Persia Sands of Time,

Splinter Cell Chaos Theory and of course Beyond 
Good &amp; Evil, a game beloved in the memories of

retro gamers that still hasn&#39;t yielded a sequel, 
which is surprising for Ubisoft considering that

all their other successful IPs have been milked 
all the way to their jaded, nonfunctioning

tearducts, but apparently it hasn&#39;t been for want 
of intention. They&#39;ve put out a new trailer for

the sequel every few years to get everyone excited 
before mysteriously going quiet about it again

with the regularity of the fucking tides, all 
prerendered teasers of course so we still know

as much about their concrete intentions for the 
game as we do about the dark side of Ganymede.

But the fact Ubisoft apparently still recognises 
the nostalgia value makes it odd there&#39;s never

been a proper remaster of Beyond Good &amp; Evil. 
Well, there was an HD release for consoles in

2011, so check that out if you still have an 
Xbox 360 or a PS3 in the room where you also

keep your mangle and your spinning jenny 
and your fucking time machine. To refresh

my memory of it this week I had to fall back on 
the slightly dodgy Steam port of the original

PC version. Which runs astonishingly well for a 
twenty-year old game in that it actually runs,

albeit mired by a ton of early 3D graphics 
teething troubles, the odd glitchy visual

effect and being apparently mystified by the 
notion that we might want to look up and down

on occasion. Still, the pseudo-cartoony 
graphics have aged surprisingly well,

as long as you don&#39;t pay too much attention 
to the facial animation and notice that the

protagonist blankly frowns her way through every 
cutscene like she stopped listening five minutes

ago and is annoyed that she&#39;s still got the 
Magic Roundabout theme tune stuck in her head.

Said protagonist is Jade, a spunky young 
photographer reporter adventurer assassin

orphanage operator with a passion for justice and 
way too many fucking jobs, living on an idyllic

world where humans coexist with sentient pigs, 
cows and walruses and if anyone asks what bacon

cheeseburgers are made from you&#39;re expected to 
subtly break eye contact and change the subject.

Jade&#39;s excellent time management skills catch the 
eye of an underground resistance group who recruit

her to join the fight against the evil authority 
that oppresses the planet under an iron fist.

Well, they say they are, but they don&#39;t seem to be 
doing much actual oppressing on the ground. Sure,

they put soldiers and propaganda screens 
everywhere but seem to mostly leave everyone

to go about their normal business of wandering 
about, racing, delivering all their voice acted

lines with slightly too much enthusiasm, and 
in Jade&#39;s case, smacking the absolute bacon

cheeseburgers out of things with a big green 
stick. Part of why Beyond Good And Evil is

remembered so fondly is that it was ahead of its 
time in so many ways. It mastered the art of being

incapable of picking one core gameplay mechanic 
to focus on way before that was the fucking norm.

In brief, it&#39;s a stealth action-adventure 
beat &#39;em up racing photography simulator.

And what impressed at the time is the way it 
balanced all of that and kept it all functional,

with the strong characters and setting putting 
the baby oil on the nude wrestling match. But note

my very deliberate use of the word &quot;functional&quot; 
rather than &quot;outstanding.&quot; Driving the hovercraft

around is probably the strongest element, it&#39;s as 
fundamentally smooth and entertaining as pushing

a disembodied tit around an air hockey table 
and the race missions make the most of it,

even if the announcer deliriously screaming all 
his lines makes me feel uncomfortably like I&#39;m

riding bay area public transport. But let&#39;s just 
say the other elements certainly don&#39;t suffer from

being OVER designed. The combat never evolves past 
&quot;twat thing with stick, occasionally pushing in a

new direction to twat different thing with stick.&quot; 
And more could&#39;ve been done with the photography

mechanic that the game revolves around, maybe 
something like what Dead Rising would later do:

award you points if you catch a beautiful shot 
of your pig dad doing one of his hilarious farts.

All of which is doing a very spirited can-can 
around the uncomfortable truth that occurs while

replaying Beyond Wooden Weevils - that for all its 
nostalgic reputation, it doesn&#39;t actually hold up

so well. Part of the problem is that every inch 
of the game screams &quot;cutbacks.&quot; Ambitions very

obviously had to be scaled down mid-development. 
The pearls are what give that away. Every

challenge in the game is rewarded with pearls that 
you use to buy upgrades for your vehicle that open

up more of the map, that&#39;s the core around 
which all progress happens, it&#39;s basically a

more diegetic version of collecting stars in Mario 
64. But at certain points you beat a story mission

and the game goes &quot;Good job! Here&#39;s fifteen 
fucking pearls to buy the next upgrade. Which

you&#39;re getting because we love you so much and not 
because we had to cut the fifteen extra sidequests

and challenges you were originally supposed to 
do to get them. Kinda wonder why they didn&#39;t

just reduce the amount of pearls the upgrade 
cost. Maybe it was the sign painter&#39;s day off.

Here&#39;s your new upgrade that grants your 
hovercraft the ability to fly. &quot;Wow,

bet this&#39;ll open all kinds of interesting new 
places to visit.&quot; Yes, if by &quot;all kinds&quot; you

mean &quot;one&quot; and by &quot;interesting new&quot; you mean 
&quot;identical to a previous place except all the

enemies drop three pearls each.&quot; Because we&#39;re 
really tired and we just want you to get this

fucker over with before you ruin your suspension 
driving over one of our vast plot holes.&quot;

Another symptom of the cut down-ness. So many 
characters and situations are just kinda there,

lacking proper introductions, so most of the 
plot twists land like watery cowpats. &quot;Hey,

the regime that has been obviously evil in what 
few direct encounters you&#39;ve had, is actually

evil. Look.&quot; &quot;Oh, so it is. What a dramatic turn 
of events that was.&quot; I think the reason why the

sequel announcement caused such excitement - 
all nineteen times it happened - is that the

original is rife with unrealised potential. 
Great music, setting and characters, but it&#39;s

like you&#39;re only glimpsing it through the holes in 
a pair of raggedy old underpants. Maybe they keep

flaking on the sequel &#39;cos expectations only get 
higher the more nostalgia-blind we get over time.

Let&#39;s just move on. Let&#39;s just say something is 
Beyond Good and Evil 2. Horizon Zero Dawn. There

you go. You&#39;re Beyond Good and Evil 2, now. And 
Kena Bridge of Spirits, you&#39;re Beyond Good and

Evil 3. Boy, this is easy. It&#39;s like the end of 
Spartacus with slightly more masculine trousers.
